comments.commentBody: In agreement with you!  How soon people here forgot the "Weapons of Mass Destruction " that didn't exist.  Those lies by the previous administration to use up our resources (no more plywood for our new housing - it went to Iraq) and the privatization of governmental functions without proper supervision (contractors), the focus on shredding the protections of the New Deal are eclipsed now by the shallowness of our current entertainment culture.  Shades of the "Fall of the Roman Empire" come to mind.
Not just the wishy washy middle off the rails but the so peculiar pundits.  This is not a sports contest.  There are consequences.
Well put.  Many members of the electorate know last night's sports scores, but don't know - or want to know - the issues.

How much more proof do we need that our electorate is as shallow as a mud puddle? One weak television appearance by the president and the wishy washy middle goes off the rails. We should hope rather that people would actually examine the opinions and ideas of the two candidates.

Mitt Romney flip-flops, lies and prevaricates and because he impersonates Ronald Reagan on the debate stump with many of the same deceptions pulled off by the Gipper, the four percent or so who remain clueless about the election are swayed. by a shallow television image.

So now we don't have an election anymore--just a marketing problem. Who can manipulate images enough to scare, bribe or deceive voters into electing them? The overreaction to the president's less than stellar performance--both the irrational exuberance of the Republicans and the despair of the Democrats shows the sad realization that neither side actually believes in their candidate--they only believe in and worry about the image their candidate projects. All surface and no substance, and a sickening disappointment for any of us who really care about the fate of our nation and who can best serve the public and the national interest.

Mark Bittman does not reference the severity of our local governments scrutiny of what goes into our water.

Many towns in California, Sunnyvale in particular, have suffered the horrible consequences of toxic and contaminated water - still births, miscarriages, adversely affected infants, and cancer in whole neighborhoods.

California is very powerful when it comes to managing toxic metals and other waste contaminates - county by county and municipality by municipality.

Fresno like many other counties in California does not have the revenues to pursue many infrastructure - clean air for example, issues at present.

But it is not as if Fresno is blind and dumb to the facts about its environment - and if Mr. Bittman traveled a little more he would see some of the more progressive results of the county.

I am very proud of California and its government works for the people and its safety.

Not sure what farmer's market's you're going to but I get close to twice as much for the money at farmer's markets.  Plus the produce stays fresh longer and I don't end up throwing away as much as I do when I shop at a grocery store.  I'm on a very tight budget and I recently did the math, and at NYC prices, farmer's markets are the way to go.

Raising a large family on a very tight budget, I have always had to prioritize expenses carefully. A few years ago after a lifetime of "eating to live" on substandard food, we decided that good food (heirloom veggies, grass fed animals, etc.) was a necessity - not a luxury. We realized that televisions, cell phones and restaurant food were the luxuries and should be cut. We focused first on finding the necessities (not an easy task!) and weaned ourselves off the luxuries. We are now tv- and cell phone-less, and we buy only good food that we prepare ourselves. We feel SO much better - blood pressure and weight are down, energy is WAY up. It's a winning cycle: enjoy great food, have energy to prepare more great food, and so on, and so on.

We have hardly missed the luxuries. Who wants to watch television after work when you can spend the time preparing gorgeous vegetables and baking delicious bread? It has become wonderful family time that we all look forward to, and the kids are becoming amazing, creative cooks. I love arriving home to this now-familiar line - "close your eyes and taste THIS, mom!"

Do you eat to live, or live to eat?
If one has the money to afford all organic, locally grown food, good for you!
Yet the majority of us must buy what we can afford and most often this does not include fancy fruits and farmer's market fare.
Many millions are on food stamps these days. Hard to stretch that budget to include even non-organic food.
The localvore, sustainable, slow food, organic crowd ought to recognize that not all have the luxury of buying, growing or raising heirloom veggies, grass fed animals or whatever.
Sure we could all try and have a garden if you've the space, time and energy.
But a majority of Americans today work long, hard hours at jobs that inhibit this entertaining idea. Just ask the maid who cleans your room, or the man who labors in some back breaking job, like picking your produce.

I was put on Ritalin at age 7. I'm now 28. At 7 I met all the criteria for ADHD. All the testing said that I had it. I was on ADHD medication daily until age 18. When they first put me on it my reaction was not a positive one. Even though I sat still and behaved, I lost all my personality and became very obsessive. Docs diagnosed any side effects as other disorders. I feel that being on Ritalin for that long has also given me long term, treatment resistant depression. Depression started in fourth grade and I was on anti-depressants by the time I was fifteen. While doctors may brush that off as a comorbid disorder, I would like to point out that drugs that act similarly in the brain such as cocaine and meth can cause the same result with long-term use. Studies on rats done in 2003 suggest that Ritalin use during the juvenile years may lead to depression later in life. In these studies, researchers from Harvard Medical School's McLean Hospital and the University of Texas Southwestern administered the drug to normal juvenile rats and discovered that depressive symptoms and decreased ability to experience pleasure could be found in these rats in adulthood. The medication seems to permanently alter the animals' brains, leading scientists to speculate whether the same thing might happen to children who take this drug. (Ran out of room, continuing in next comment if I can...)
I feel very damaged from being put on Ritalin as a child. I wish they had left me alone. Please see my comments further along on this thread.

This is especially maddening to people like me who KNOW that ADD/ADHD exists, but find it hard to blame people for not believing in it. Myself, I was diagnosed before the term even existed (it was described as "A severe attentional disorder), when my doctor had to explain the concept to my teachers who'd never heard of it, and Dexedrine was common medication for the uncommon diagnosis. I know it is a real condition because I still live with it. I have a hard time focusing on things I want to focus on. People around me even ask if something's on my mind not realizing that what appears to be "something on my mind" or "distracted by something" is my normal state. I hope no one minds my saying this, least of all my wife, but I can't keep my mind from wandering even when having sex! It's real, but 9% of the population do not have it.

Further, it involves the parietal lobe of the brain (ADD does, ADHD is in the frontal), and there are other things that are impacted, such as right and left. My wife could tell you about my saying, "Turn right... no left... no... that way!" You'd think doctors could use that to make a real diagnosis rather than just assuming someone is ADD because they are getting bad grades. As for the danger of medication, the Dexedrine made me badly depressed back when I didn't know what depression was (and no one would have believed a kid could be depressed). I can only imagine what this stuff is doing to kids who don't even have ADD. No wonder the disbelief!

While I do not share Dr. Anderson's belief that offering speed to children is a reasonable solution to address socio-economic imbalance, I share his sentiment, expressed here by so many, that there is insufficient attention placed on helping parents to more effectively manage complex kids. As a parent in a diagnosed-ADHD Family of 5, we manage each of our family member's ADHD differently, depending on the way it shows up for that individual. Parent Coaching was the single 'treatment' option provided so much improvement for each member of the family that I actually became a certified coach, myself, and founded ImpactADHD.com, a free resource site for parents of kids with ADHD. Fee-based services are available, but we offer a HUGE amount of support to parents for free-- because the need is clear.

Parents are the Missing Link in ADHD Management. When parents engage, understand their child's ADHD, and take action to manage it consciously, their kids are more likely to become independent and successful adults. We can throw medication and accommodations at kids all day long, but when their parents take the bull by the horns, create structures and accountabilities with understanding and compassion, the entire family thrives.

I hope Dr. Anderson will tell his patients' parents to visit ImpactADHD.com -- it's free, and offers another way for him to correct the social injustice he witnesses that does not involve controlled prescription medications.

Students with attentional issues need modifications that oftentimes require extra staff for one on one attention to guide them through classroom assignments. No one wants to pay for this. My state has cut education funding 50 million dollars in the past 6 years and shows no interest in reinstating funding to pre-recession levels. We are doing all that we can with what we have. Repeating the line about "failing schools" doesn't reflect the fact that society is failing these kids. It didn't start the day they entered school and won't end the day they leave it. Their issues run much deeper and require resources far greater than anyone, let alone the average tax-payer, is willing to commit. I can teach your kids, but I can't raise them.

% GDP on educ. % male literacy % female literacy
